Anyway, your Cinder fix is the right way to handle the logging problems, but we'll need to configure this at some point anyway.

Also I opened this bug to encourage somebody to document the cinder element:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-10 18:46:18.000000000', 'message': "Adds cinder.keymgr.fixed_key to cinder element

Not having keymgr.fixed_key causes tons of WARNING messages like:

 WARNING cinder.keymgr.conf_key_mgr [-] config option keymgr.fixed_key
 has not been defined: some operations may fail unexpectedly

Once this lands we can add a bit of overcloud metadata so we set
a reasonable default for this (perhaps 'unset' even)...

Change-Id: I8cf41379aae0e0ed460c4b27f7279796c8ad8f8d
"}]
commit_message:
Adds cinder.keymgr.fixed_key to cinder element

Not having keymgr.fixed_key causes tons of WARNING messages like:

 WARNING cinder.keymgr.conf_key_mgr [-] config option keymgr.fixed_key
 has not been defined: some operations may fail unexpectedly

Once this lands we can add a bit of overcloud metadata so we set
a reasonable default for this (perhaps 'unset' even)...

Change-Id: I8cf41379aae0e0ed460c4b27f7279796c8ad8f8d

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-01 08:17:48.000000000', 'message': "Configurable cell_class in DataTable.

There are two changes in this proposal. One is to move the logic
for extracting cell data from the row datum (and handling auto columns)
to the Cell class, into a separate method for easy extending. The
second is to make that extending possible by making the cell class
configurable in the DataTable's meta.

Those changes are supposed to make it easier to extend the DataTable
with new kinds of cells -- for example, cells that contain an editable
widget, a progress bar, an icon, etc. as well as make it easier to
modify the behavior of the auto columns -- for example, by making it
possible to have some of the multi_select checkboxes preselected. Those
changes would also make it easier to integrate DataTable with a Django
FormSet.

Right now, in order to modify any of the proposed Cell.get_data
behavior, one has to make their own Row class and practically copy-paste
the whole Row.load_cells method, as there is no easy way to extend it.

Change-Id: I29277a9e77e1c413193fe80d3f8cfe001bf5d709

commit_message:
Configurable cell_class in DataTable

There are two changes in this proposal. One is to move the logic
for extracting cell data from the row datum (and handling auto columns)
to the Cell class, into a separate method for easy extending. The
second is to make that extending possible by making the cell class
configurable in the DataTable's meta.

Those changes are supposed to make it easier to extend the DataTable
with new kinds of cells -- for example, cells that contain an editable
widget, a progress bar, an icon, etc. as well as make it easier to
modify the behavior of the auto columns -- for example, by making it
possible to have some of the multi_select checkboxes preselected. Those
changes would also make it easier to integrate DataTable with a Django
FormSet.

Right now, in order to modify any of the proposed Cell.get_data
behavior, one has to make their own Row class and practically copy-paste
the whole Row.load_cells method, as there is no easy way to extend it.

Change-Id: I29277a9e77e1c413193fe80d3f8cfe001bf5d709
Closes-Bug: #1229677

[{'created': '2013-12-10 09:39:46.000000000', 'message': "Run selenium tests only when requested

In some environments, it's not wanted or possible
to execute selenium tests. These are only executed, if
--with-selenium is specified.

Change-Id: I39c40ac1feb64565f0bcbc97f6345d203b1d816e
Closes-Bug: 1259072
"}]
commit_message:
Run selenium tests only when requested

In some environments, it's not wanted or possible
to execute selenium tests. These are only executed, if
--with-selenium is specified.

Change-Id: I39c40ac1feb64565f0bcbc97f6345d203b1d816e
Closes-Bug: 1259072

[{'created': '2013-12-09 20:36:07.000000000', 'message': 'Adds Trove mock to tests in database_backups

Test cases in database_backups/tests.py now have a mock for the
method api.trove.instance_get(). The absence of this mock was
causing real HTTP requests to Trove.

Change-Id: Icf760d7eaba2d136626dbbbbf6e49260a18fb874
Closes-Bug: #1255936
'}]
commit_message:
Adds Trove mock to tests in database_backups

Test cases in database_backups/tests.py now have a mock for the
method api.trove.instance_get(). The absence of this mock was
causing real HTTP requests to Trove.

Change-Id: Icf760d7eaba2d136626dbbbbf6e49260a18fb874
Closes-Bug: #1255936

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-21 15:29:30.000000000', 'message': 'Allow translators to control word order of BatchAction message

Currently BatchAction message is generated by concatenating
'action' and 'data_type'. In most cases 'action' is a verb
and 'data_type' is an object. However in some action such as
TerminateInstance 'action' is a combination of verb and
object (e.g., "Scheduled termination of").  It is hard that
translators find translated strings which covers both cases.

This commit allows classes inheriting BatchAction to specify
a full action name containing '%(data_type)s' substitution
in action_present/ action_past so that translators can
control the order of phrases completely.

* _conjugate() in actions.py is renamed to _get_action_name()
  because this method no longer always conjugate words.
* Changes action_past strings which are not a form of verb + obj
  to strings with "%(data_type)s"

Closes-Bug: #1253678
Change-Id: I3cf1dc74e22745eb3a9bd2edc3ec68ed389495b5
'}, {'created': '2013-12-10 14:24:29.000000000', 'message': 'Allow translators to control word order of BatchAction message

commit_message:
Allow translators to control word order of BatchAction message

Currently BatchAction message is generated by concatenating
'action' and 'data_type'. In most cases 'action' is a verb
and 'data_type' is an object. However in some action such as
TerminateInstance 'action' is a combination of verb and
object (e.g., "Scheduled termination of").  It is hard that
translators find translated strings which covers both cases.

This commit allows classes inheriting BatchAction to specify
a full action name containing '%(data_type)s' substitution
in action_present/ action_past so that translators can
control the order of phrases completely.

* _conjugate() in actions.py is renamed to _get_action_name()
  because this method no longer always conjugate words.
* Changes action_past strings which are not a form of verb + obj
  to strings with "%(data_type)s"

Closes-Bug: #1253678
Change-Id: I3cf1dc74e22745eb3a9bd2edc3ec68ed389495b5

The TC applies a number of criteria when considering project incubation
and graduation to integrated status, and when considering new programs.
These reference documents should track the minimal requirements that we
apply, so that candidate projects and teams know what is expected of
them.

These documents, by nature, do not contain all the criteria that each
member of the TC will apply when evaluating applications. They are
just the ever-evolving minimal set of requirements that are consensual
amongst TC members.

NB: Some currently-incubated, currently-integrated or currently-official
projects and programs do not fill all of those requirements, as some of
them are new requirements we recently imposed to raise the quality of
the end-result, based on past experience. Those teams and projects
should try to cover the gap during the Icehouse cycle.

commit_message:
Incubation / Graduation / New program requirements

The TC applies a number of criteria when considering project incubation
and graduation to integrated status, and when considering new programs.
These reference documents should track the minimal requirements that we
apply, so that candidate projects and teams know what is expected of
them.

These documents, by nature, do not contain all the criteria that each
member of the TC will apply when evaluating applications. They are
just the ever-evolving minimal set of requirements that are consensual
amongst TC members.

NB: Some currently-incubated, currently-integrated or currently-official
projects and programs do not fill all of those requirements, as some of
them are new requirements we recently imposed to raise the quality of
the end-result, based on past experience. Those teams and projects
should try to cover the gap during the Icehouse cycle.

Change-Id: Ieedc64a20135e3498786bee6fc54d91b9cf2a93a

Code looks good. Please just add a line in the git history explaining why we need the change."}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-12-10 02:06:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I think the point about multiple repos is a good one.

http://forums.opensuse.org/english/get-technical-help-here/applications/437610-how-make-zypper-use-proxy.html

suggests /etc/zypp/zypp.conf, or something called aria2c, or /etc/sysconfig/proxy.

But really - it looks like zypp honours http_proxy, so do we need to do this at all?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-12-10 06:51:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Doesn't the "do we need this at all" question also apply to yum and apt?

i.e. yum respects http_proxy too, so why are we setting it in in yum.conf?'}, {'account_id': 2062, 'date': '2013-12-10 07:58:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I am a bit confused now (basically about the same point as Mark). I had the impression that the goal was to only use a proxy for the package management tool (apt, yum, zypper) and not systemwide. If the proxy setting can be systemwide I am more than happy to add it to /etc/sysconfig/proxy. It make things even easier :)

BTW, aria2c is just an alternative downloader that zypper can use. By default is uses curl which should handle proxies just fine.

There doesn't seem to be a way set a proxy for zypper in zypp.conf the only alternative to adding it to the repo files seems to be set it globally for the whole system it seems (or via the http_proxy env variable)."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-12-10 14:52:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2062, 'date': '2013-12-10 14:57:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-12-10 14:58:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
local-config: Configure proxy for zypper repos

This allows using the local-config element with openSUSE based images.

Closes-Bug: #1256982
Change-Id: I670c938a44095ea7e7c31b81194acc1555212f06

commit_message:
Updates tox.ini to use new features

tox 1.6 allows us to skip the sdist step, which
is slow. This does that.
It also allows us to override the install line.
In this case, it's important as it allows us to
stop getting pre-release software we were not
asking for.

Original patch by Monty Taylor, talked about here:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-September/015495.html

Change-Id: Iddf85d33b57f256d72756b516c23492e9600bedc

commit_message:
Handle rest client 500 response if non-json body

* Rest client should gracefully handle 500 response from api
  with non-json body.
* Use response body as is in case of above issue.

Change-Id: I1adf2e0af0abead0767d628142a18916154ada79
Closes-Bug: #950449

commit_message:
Sync global requirements to pin sphinx to
sphinx>=1.1.2,<1.2

Sync the global requirements to pin sphinx.

This addresses an issue where Sphinx 1.2 is not
building documents correctly and causing
check/gate to fail.

Change-Id: I208cb6b11fb4a3e1c4bb726f8adea24b6db76756

commit_message:
Fix dev version package spec in requirements.txt

'-' in #egg section is treated like a separator,
inside egg_info, which is not desirable.

Change-Id: Ic857b45a99614c96a245e158936220dea557db7c

commit_message:
Use correct types for thresholds

Currently in this template parameters have type Number, but
CloudWatchAlarm has threshold type String. This fix change
Type parameters to String.

Change-Id: If7030063f8bae6b70648a07acb086c341a75373f

I might be missing some background here, but I wonder why we cannot simply use CONF.host instead of engine_id (I vaguely remember there was some discussion about this)? That way, we could avoid the use of the EngineListener by moving the listening method to EngineService and sending the rpc call to a specific node_topic, e.g. rpc.call(self.context, msg, topic='%s.%s' % (topic, host), timeout=cfg.CONF.engine_life_check_timeout)"}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-11-20 10:51:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Liang - because we want a new engine ID every time the process starts up. That way if a process dies while holding a lock, we know to steal it back even if it respawns on that host.'}, {'account_id': 7135, 'date': '2013-11-20 14:16:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Implement stack-locking for multi-engine support

Implements a distributed stack lock using the database to avoid race
conditions when multiple engines are deployed.

Blueprint multiple-engines

Change-Id: If3c47dafcc5bc1b2188b7737205291bbab8bc231

subject: Database changes for multi-engine support

commit_message:
Database changes for multi-engine support

Add a stack_lock database table to use as a distributed stack lock to
avoid race conditions when multiple engines are deployed.

Blueprint multiple-engines

Change-Id: I0b8e244a73295dca307cb09ea5da2ebe709134b1

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-11 00:39:38.000000000', 'message': "Remove outdated libvirt_vif_driver settings

There is no longer a need to modify the libvirt_vif_driver conf
setting, it should always be the default value of:

libvirt_vif_driver=nova.virt.libvirt.vif.LibvirtGenericVIFDriver

This patch removes any reference to deprecated options for the
libvirt_vif_driver parameter.

Closes-bug #1192833

As a side-effect, this patch removes a section that contains this note:

      <note>
        <para>When using libvirt < 0.9.11, one must also edit
            <filename>/etc/libvirt/qemu.conf</filename>, uncomment the
          entry for 'cgroup_device_acl', add the value '/dev/net/tun'
          to the list of items for the configuration entry, and then
          restart libvirtd.</para>
      </note>

It's not clear to me whether this is required or not with the
generic VIF driver plugin.

Change-Id: I233b18c8021bae6218faee63828c093d9b5b883d
backport: havana
(cherry picked from commit a31f8101cbf103916cc0b293a66ccb9bf96d46e1)
"}]
commit_message:
Remove outdated libvirt_vif_driver settings

There is no longer a need to modify the libvirt_vif_driver conf
setting, it should always be the default value of:

libvirt_vif_driver=nova.virt.libvirt.vif.LibvirtGenericVIFDriver

This patch removes any reference to deprecated options for the
libvirt_vif_driver parameter.

Closes-bug #1192833

As a side-effect, this patch removes a section that contains this note:

      <note>
        <para>When using libvirt < 0.9.11, one must also edit
            <filename>/etc/libvirt/qemu.conf</filename>, uncomment the
          entry for 'cgroup_device_acl', add the value '/dev/net/tun'
          to the list of items for the configuration entry, and then
          restart libvirtd.</para>
      </note>

It's not clear to me whether this is required or not with the
generic VIF driver plugin.

Change-Id: I233b18c8021bae6218faee63828c093d9b5b883d
backport: havana
(cherry picked from commit a31f8101cbf103916cc0b293a66ccb9bf96d46e1)

commit_message:
Sync global requirements to pin sphinx to sphinx>=1.1.2,<1.2

Sync the global requirements to pin sphinx. This addresses an issue
where Sphinx 1.2 is not building documents correctly and causing
check/gate to fail.

Change-Id: I0334a4b1789211f54cdeee965fd62d9a9346f16f

commit_message:
This is the initial commit of the savanna puppet module.

Installs the OpenStack savanna UI and backend. Example of
use can be seen in example/example.pp

Implements: blueprint puppet-savanna

Change-Id: Id9d94949e7f6ec6e69d87dd4bc6db2e3d0163e64

commit_message:
Fix -a opt to boot-seed-vm.

Fixes an issue in 444c63128d0354c97d66a3bb5b8e23ea39633bbb where
we changed the behaviour of the -a argument. The -a option requires
an argument as well...

Change-Id: I68f8d5b0ea5d13b5136ae854e681892d48eeda90

commit_message:
ML2 plugin basic configuration

This is initial documentation for basic configuration of ML2 plugin.
ML2 configuration and use cases documented by Sukhdev and closed by patchset for Bug #1230276
So this document patchset relates both to Bug #1230266 and #1230276

Change-Id: I3b7b42bf5f340b5034b8362c0805730fd671d307
Closes-Bug: #1230266

I have a question for this bug, and put it in https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1245775 . Thanks."}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2013-10-29 16:06:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Thanks for the patch but I think it is invalid.

safe_delete_from_backend is expected to delete the requested image SAFELY, otherwise delete_from_backend should be used."}, {'account_id': 7701, 'date': '2013-10-29 17:43:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi zhi, fei.
Thanks a lot for the review. There are plenty of situations, for instance an image to be deleted is not in the store. If this simply catches the "Not Found" without raising it, the calling request continues execution as if nothing went wrong. This does happen a lot during upload_data_to_store when a safe_kill is initiated and the image does not seem to exist!! Couple of other scenarios too.'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-10-31 07:46:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

So Amala the root problem to me for this defect is that why those code does calling on "store.safe_delete_from_backend()" but "store.delete_from_backend()"? IMO we need find out those code which expect catch exception when it require remove image bits from backend storage, and change them to using "delete_from_backend()" (if needed) but "safe_delete_from_backend()". Any thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 7701, 'date': '2013-11-04 06:11:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks for the review zhi! Your concern is perfectly valid. From the code, this safe_delete_from_backend seems to be called in upload_utils while an update_to_store happens and a mismatch or something requires a deletion. This seems to be fine, but safe_delete is also called during a normal controller delete as well. In such a scenario, I dont really think swallowing an exception is a good idea. Either we should change this bit of code to call delete_from_backend or just raise the appropriate exception here. Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-11-04 06:45:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Amala Basha, I prefer go former way, thanks.'}, {'account_id': 7701, 'date': '2013-11-04 09:06:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The concern with that approach is that both need checks for a delayed delete case. One workaround would be to make the upload_utils method indirectly work like a safe_delete by catching the exception there, and raising it again here.'}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2013-11-05 22:49:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Reviewed this briefly, some points that I feel like sharing:
1. Can we have appropriate link to the bug (auto-generated by gerrit) as Zhi suggested.
2. I'm not sure how it should be for using a single mock test in a file where all others are using Mox. May be we should modify the existing tests "related to this bug only" to use mock if we have to use mock.
3. Is there a place where the UnsupportedBackend Exception is being caught. May be we should have a test for the same, nonetheless.'}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2013-11-05 22:51:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(I'm sorry the formatting did not come out great, trying again)

Reviewed this briefly, some points that I feel like sharing: 

1. Can we have appropriate link to the bug (auto-generated by gerrit) as Zhi suggested.

2. I'm not sure how it should be for using a single mock test in a file where all others are using Mox. May be we should modify the existing tests "related to this bug only" to use mock if we have to use mock. 

3. Is there a place where the UnsupportedBackend Exception is being caught. revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-29 07:19:11.000000000', 'message': 'safe_delete_from_backend does not raise exceptions

The safe_delete_from_backend in glance/store/__init__.py does not raise
the appropriate exceptions. For eg) In situations where delete of non existent image is attempted,
it simply sends off a warning without raising the Not Found Exception. As a result the end response
received for the request is deceiving.

Fixes Bug #1245775
Change-Id: I10cb04a135cc9611f7144192e790693f81788d5b

commit_message:
Controller delete should raise exceptions

The safe_delete_from_backend in glance/store/__init__.py does not raise
the appropriate exceptions. For eg) In situations where delete of non
existent image is attempted,
it simply sends off a warning without raising the Not Found Exception.
As a result the end response
received for the request is deceiving. Main points to note:

1) safe_delete is being called from the controller delete as well as
from an upload_data_to_store during a mismatch.
2) Upload errors should catch the exceptions and safely delete
3) The controller delete should raise back the caught exception

Fixes bug #1245775
Change-Id: I10cb04a135cc9611f7144192e790693f81788d5b

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-27 12:19:10.000000000', 'message': 'Closes-Bug: #1252314 Support for Windows in Virtualbox scripts

Added support for Cygwin.\n Increased default disk and memory sizes.\n per QA request: Default NIC number increased to 5 per slave VM.\n Added checks for non-installed Cygwin components\n Default NIC type changed to faster AMD PCnet FAST III.

Change-Id: I851913f6ce1a33b7fa152ae3f7fe88260d6309de
'}]
commit_message:
Closes-Bug: #1252314 Support for Windows in Virtualbox scripts

Added support for Cygwin.\n Increased default disk and memory sizes.\n per QA request: Default NIC number increased to 5 per slave VM.\n Added checks for non-installed Cygwin components\n Default NIC type changed to faster AMD PCnet FAST III.

Change-Id: I851913f6ce1a33b7fa152ae3f7fe88260d6309de

Thanks for the review.

Given the nature of your other comments, do you think it's best to skip reuse using a create/remove pair and instead go with straight forward rmdir (x2) calls and putting that code back inline?"}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-12-03 05:53:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

If this is just designed to prevent concurrent execution, could we just remove this entirely and recommend deployers use something like flock(1) to prevent concurrent execution by cron? ...or is it a requirement that manual invocations also be protected?'}, {'account_id': 6714, 'date': '2013-12-03 06:07:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I would assume so since dump_recon_cache does its own lock_file management.

For that matter, should we be using lock_path/lock_file in swift.common.utils instead of the mkdir/rmdir?'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-12-03 16:51:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Well, I'd vote for ripping out all the locking stuff in here, updating all the relevant documentation guides, etc. which mention this cron job and make them use flock(1).

Then we make sure John (notmyname) adds a prominent mention in the release notes for the subsequent release which says something like "existing deployments should add flock(1) concurrent-execution-protection to their recon collector crontab entries".

I asked some of the "old timers" in IRC why this was done in preference to something like flock(1), but I haven't heard anything back yet.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-12-11 06:03:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-12-11 06:03:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-15 17:47:54.000000000', 'message': 'Remove lock_dir on script failures

Under certain circunstances, if get_async_count or dump_cron_cache calls
fail, the lock_dir is not remved. All subsequent executions of
swift-recon-cron will fail with [Errno 17] file exists and will also die
until the lock_dir is manually removed.

- Move create/remove lock code into methods
- Wrap the get_async_count/dump_cron_cache calls wit bettwe exception
handling to ensure the lock_dir is always removed

Change-Id: I7bfe4c7871aa5fbc77078344dffe0e2a0bb2fc2e
Closes-Bug: #1251713
'}]
commit_message:
Remove lock_dir on script failures

Under certain circunstances, if get_async_count or dump_cron_cache calls
fail, the lock_dir is not remved. All subsequent executions of
swift-recon-cron will fail with [Errno 17] file exists and will also die
until the lock_dir is manually removed.

- Move create/remove lock code into methods
- Wrap the get_async_count/dump_cron_cache calls wit bettwe exception
handling to ensure the lock_dir is always removed

Change-Id: I7bfe4c7871aa5fbc77078344dffe0e2a0bb2fc2e
Closes-Bug: #1251713

Allow time for keystone service to restart after a keystone-manage
db_sync run to ensure that subsequent keystone queries do not get
connection refused errors.

'}, {'created': '2013-12-03 17:47:51.000000000', 'message': 'Allow time for keystone restart after db_sync

commit_message:
Allow time for keystone restart after db_sync

Allow time for keystone service to restart after a keystone-manage
db_sync run to ensure that subsequent keystone queries do not get
connection refused errors.

Partial-Bug: #1255149
Change-Id: I5d57010736536495bf2e5cc0d094f2f602770ab1

'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-11-13 22:36:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-11-13 22:42:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Not opposed to the idea but our driver mapping keeps growing every release.  In fact last cycle some mappings were modified because people were upset they weren't using longer names :)

Anyway, I don't mind doing this but maybe we should look at this as a whole and just finally make a lasting change and quit messing with these mappings rather than churning on it every release?"}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-11-13 23:11:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

John: Not sure I follow.  What kind of lasting change could you make that would prevent having to update classpaths?  Updates still need to happen when code moves around.

You could have each driver class specify an identifier, but then the volume manager has to load every driver.  We do this in the scheduler already, so it's clearly possible, but not sure we want to...


We could make it configurable:
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py?id=8f419f801#n166"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-11-13 23:18:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2013-11-19 12:04:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-11-19 15:31:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

John/Edward:

I don't understand the objections here.  We currently insist that *users* maintain knowledge of driver classpaths.  This is not reasonable.

Yes it is a small amount of work for us to maintain a mapping.  But it's something that we should be doing.

Yes, we should have a mapping for each driver name.  But it is not appropriate for me to decide the name for every driver in Cinder.  (I mean, I could, but I think most driver maintainers would prefer to decide that themselves since it's partly a branding decision.  I don't want people complaining later that I have caused them to be stuck with a name they don't like.)

It may make sense to move the "mapping" out of a dict and into a field in each driver, but we still need to have each driver owner maintain the knowledge somewhere in Cinder.'}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2013-11-22 00:02:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Yet another mapping.   I agree with Eric that it's a nice to have for admins, but also agree with John in that it adds more overhead moving forward to ensure that this mapping is kept in sync.   Also, what do we do in the case where we have 2 drivers for different firmware versions of a backend ( I don't think we have this anywhere now though)? Say a LeftHand 1.0 and a LeftHand 2.0 ? What would the mapping look like then?

We have 2 3par drivers, iSCSI and FC, I presume the mappings would look something like this?

'3pariscsi' : 'cinder.volume.drivers.san.hp.hp_3par_iscsi.HP3PARISCSIDriver', 
'3parfc' : 'cinder.volume.drivers.san.hp.hp_3par_fc.HP3PARFCDriver',

I think at a minimum though we need to have coverage for all the drivers."}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-11-22 14:53:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Walt:  Yes, if you have two different drivers for a similar backend, you would need to give them different names.

"I think at a minimum though we need to have coverage for all the drivers." 
  -- I agree, but I don't think this should be done in the first patch.  We could start the list now (can leave the code turned off that uses it if you think necessary) and tell driver owners that if they don't add a name by icehouse-3, I'll name their driver for them.  How does that sound?'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-11-26 17:24:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-11-26 18:08:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-11-26 18:21:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2013-11-26 18:31:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Like other people who've -1'd above, I think this is of little gain and the cost of yet another mapping table is definite.... we want to be getting rid of mapping tables, not adding them"}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-11-26 18:33:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2013-11-26 18:33:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

See above -1s"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-11-26 19:21:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

- check-grenade-devstack-vm http://logs.openstack.org/46/22246/7/check/check-grenade-devstack-vm/e97c2cf : SUCCESS in 24m 19s
'}, {'account_id': 9236, 'date': '2013-11-26 22:48:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I think this is a very useful feature to have.  It improves configuration by reducing the likelihood of typos and increased readability.  By maintaining a map in Cinder, we remove the need for the user to remember this mapping.'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-12-03 22:19:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-12-11 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Abandoned

commit_message:
Allow short names for volume_driver in cinder.conf

This allows configuring the volume driver like:
volume_driver="nfs"
instead of
volume_driver="cinder.volume.drivers.nfs.NfsDriver"

The setting is also treated as case-insensitive to allow "LVM" or
"lvm", etc.

Driver identifiers not listed in the translation table will be
treated as class paths, as before.

Change-Id: I9e28e2afb07c88353a546a87e76a3220b051c9f2

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-03 22:14:24.000000000', 'message': 'Stale kvm processes when using libguestfs

When setting up images for nova there is insufficient error handling
when using libguestfs which leaves stale kvm processes on the compute
node.  These stale processes consume CPU and memory and can starve a
compute node of resources.  The stale processes are not reaped when the
instance that triggered the libguestfs injection is deleted.

Change-Id: I96ed4fc6871af0134c69fc3b2d39a750a5e5d0f2
Partial-Bug: #1246852
'}]
commit_message:
Stale kvm processes when using libguestfs

When setting up images for nova there is insufficient error handling
when using libguestfs which leaves stale kvm processes on the compute
node.  These stale processes consume CPU and memory and can starve a
compute node of resources.  The stale processes are not reaped when the
instance that triggered the libguestfs injection is deleted.

Change-Id: I96ed4fc6871af0134c69fc3b2d39a750a5e5d0f2
Partial-Bug: #1246852

commit_message:
Sync Log Levels from OSLO

The iso8601 debug messages were spamming neutron-server's logs.

cbfded9c Default iso8601 logging to WARN

Change-Id: I526813fd4b29e23977c459c70ac63d87bd33b849
Closes-Bug: 1257396

'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-09-25 18:24:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I've read the blueprint and can understand the use case, I'm just really worried that the term 'access key' will confuse people, since in oauth1, there is a concept of an `access token` that has an `access key` and `access secret`."}, {'account_id': 7052, 'date': '2013-09-25 20:20:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Steve,
  I have no problem with name changes. Please feel free to suggest some names that would disambiguate the different cases.
Thanks,
Fabio'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-09-30 23:58:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm a little unsure of what this is intended to be. 

As it stands with access and secret, how is this more secure than using a randomly generated long password and a user id?

If on the other hand you are providing a nonce and encrypting it to verify the correctness of a pre-shared key or availability of a private key then that is interesting (and the right way to do key validation), but i see no sign of that, and you would probably need a few more parameters to do it.

I'm not sure what 'access' as a key identifier is for in the 1 user has 1 key scenario, why not just user user_id/username it makes some sense in the 1-M scenario but that doesn't seem to be the case from the blueprint. 

What is the plan for using this in a project/domain scoped token? 

The part of this that is most relevant to an API extension is going to be the CRUD operations around user keys. This is missing from the patch. On that note (and around the federation reviews) it would be good if we could have somewhere to put auth-plugin extensions that don't have an associated API change."}, {'account_id': 220, 'date': '2013-10-02 05:06:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Steve,

Those who have used AWS would know about accesskey/secret key very well. It is well know term'}, {'account_id': 7052, 'date': '2013-10-02 15:55:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Jaimie,
  the main difference between the password and the access-key is that you can rotate keys on a regular base increasing the security.
My understanding is that users cannot have multiple passwords at the same time.
Moreover, keys can be rotated without service interruption, since you can activate the new key and roll it out whilst maintaining the old key active until the process is terminate and then revoke the old key.'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-10-04 00:34:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: No score

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 7052, 'date': '2013-10-04 14:51:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-10-04 21:50:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Is this different from the Credentials?"}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-10-04 23:55:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-10-04 23:57:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Adam, this is not credential API. This is an authentication plugin making use of a specific type of credential, which is managed by credential API.'}, {'account_id': 7052, 'date': '2013-10-07 16:30:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-10-07 16:30:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

(3 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-10-08 15:23:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

Fabio, please remove the description pretending to decryption. There shouldn't be any crypto involved for access key authentication."}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-10-08 18:48:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-10-08 19:29:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 220, 'date': '2013-10-09 05:32:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

This blueprint is too specific.  We have credentials resource and it has a type.attribute. Instead of creating a blueprint for each and every credential type, can't we create one auth method for handling  credential type.

auth : {
  method : generic_credential
  type  : credential type ( this should match the type attribute of credential resource)
  blob : {

  }

}"}, {'account_id': 220, 'date': '2013-10-09 05:36:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This blueprint is too specific. We have credentials resource and it has a type.attribute. Instead of creating a blueprint for each and every credential type, can't we create one auth method for handling credential type.

auth : {
method : generic_credential
type : credential type ( this should match the type attribute of credential resource)
blob : {
   credential type specific data structure
}
}

So if we have a credential of type "accessKey", then it will becoome "accessKey" auth and if  we have a credential of type "MyCustomCredentila", it will map to that credential type.'}, {'account_id': 7052, 'date': '2013-10-11 18:12:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-10-11 18:19:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-11-19 02:48:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24: Do not merge

OK, I've been thinking about this for a long while.  Before we move ahead, we have to make sure that we are not doing an end run around security.  As I see it, this is really propigating some bad practices>  Shared secrets are really not a good approach to security, and this makes them really a first class citizen in Keystone.

The behavior you want can be done outside of Keystone:  use Basic-Auth and "external" and you will have the same basic functionality.  Using the mapping rules, you can determine how to map the REMOTE_USER variable to the userid.

If the user is provisioned from a Federated identity store, the multiple password mechanism could be used to bypass the disable check.  

I'm still not convinced that having multiple user objects in the Keystone table is not the right abstraction for implementing this.  There does not have to be a 1 to 1 between user objects in Keystone and the users in your external CRM system.'}, {'account_id': 9098, 'date': '2013-11-20 20:13:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This seems like a bad idea from a security standpoint.  The proposal is really adding the ability to have multiple passwords (shared secrets) tied to a single user.  The blueprint refers to these as keys and compares them to SSH keys, but this is really just a clear-text password, not a public/private key pair.

In general, having multiple passwords for a single user is a bad idea.  Consider the case where Keystone is using LDAP for authentication.  If one's LDAP account is locked-out for some reason, they would be able to bypass that if they have a shared-secret stored in Keystone.  We shouldn't allow that.

It seems like you should just be able to create additional service accounts in Keystone for your use-case and store your secret as the pasword.  This wouldn't require any API changes.  Is there a reason why this isn't sufficient?"}, {'account_id': 8116, 'date': '2013-11-20 20:42:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't really understand the motivation for the proposal, it seems ill
conceived from a security standpoint.

The blueprint uses the term key as if it were a cryptographic
key but there seems to be little to support that notion. Instead it
seems as if this is just a secondary shared secret (i.e. password).
Multiple passwords are a security hazard because N possible passwords
could potentially grant access, this makes account lock-down and
revocation harder.

If the idea is to grant access to multiple users then policy and roles
would be a better approach.

I can't find a justification in the blueprint that warrants the change."}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-11-20 22:26:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

"This seems like a bad idea from a security standpoint. The proposal is really adding the ability to have multiple passwords (shared secrets) tied to a single user. The blueprint refers to these as keys and compares them to SSH keys, but this is really just a clear-text password, not a public/private key pair."

In reality, user is allowed to have multiple credentials. For example, your wallet may have multiple credit cards. :) Security is a process, software is a tool. What we are proposing is a solution to solve a problem. Just because it is not acceptable for some doesn't mean it is not acceptable for all. I really don't want to turn this into a religious debate. We don't tell deployers what is security and what's not. That's up to them to determine. In reality, different industries have different security-related requirements. For example, deployers who have to deal with SOX compliance may have a different view on security then those who have to deal with HIPAA-compliance. If OpenStack wants wide adoption, it has to be flexible.


"In general, having multiple passwords for a single user is a bad idea. Consider the case where Keystone is using LDAP for authentication. If one's LDAP account is locked-out for some reason, they would be able to bypass that if they have a shared-secret stored in Keystone. We shouldn't allow that."

You don't suspend/disable the user credential, you suspend/disable the user.


"It seems like you should just be able to create additional service accounts in Keystone for your use-case and store your secret as the pasword. This wouldn't require any API changes. Is there a reason why this isn't sufficient?"

Its all about usuability. Asking services to joggle multiple accounts may be a bit overkill. In production, maintaining multiple accounts for billing, auditing, etc is quite a bit of work. We should give deployer an option for not having to aggregating over multiple accounts to do somethign as simple as password rotation.


"I don't really understand the motivation for the proposal, it seems ill conceived from a security standpoint."

As I mentioned before, security is a process, software is a tool. We don't dictate security, we simply facilitate it.

"The blueprint uses the term key as if it were a cryptographic key but there seems to be little to support that notion. Instead it seems as if this is just a secondary shared secret (i.e. password). Multiple passwords are a security hazard because N possible passwords could potentially grant access, this makes account lock-down and revocation harder."

Forget about cryptographic operations, that's not what this is for. There's no "encryption/decryption" involved. We can submit another blueprint if you like.


"If the idea is to grant access to multiple users then policy and roles would be a better approach."

Use case is for password rotation for rolling upgrades.'}, {'account_id': 7052, 'date': '2013-11-20 23:14:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

Folks,
  we have implemented this at HP following what it appears to be an "industry standard" approach:

Rackspace has its own version:
http://docs.rackspace.com/servers/api/v2/cs-devguide/content/curl_auth.html

AWS too:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/aws-sec-cred-types.html

This is a simple and pragmatic approach for facilitate password rotation without service interruption.

Moreover Openstack has something similar in EC2 and Swift Sync.

My 2c.'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-11-21 22:24:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24:

I'm confused:
http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-identity-service/2.0/content/POST_authenticate_v2.0_tokens_.html

already accepts username and password - I'm unclear how this differs. If the concern is the ability to create temporary additional passwords for a username, I can see why thats concerning : but the use case is fairly clear:

 - assume there are N services running
 - with existing username+passwords

How do we change their passwords? If we:

 - change password
 - update config

Then the service is down until the config update is done.

If we:

 - update config
 - change password

Then the service is down until the password change is done.

If we:

 - add new user
 - update config
 - delete old user

Then we have to also change every other service that expects those users to expect new users: we're just shifting the burden."}, {'account_id': 7060, 'date': '2013-11-22 14:08:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Sharing the same user among multiple service when not necessary is a bad idea.

Besides causing you to want to have these odd features to store multiple passwords, it also means that if any one services is compromised then all of your other services are. 
So instead of blocking one now you may have to go and fix all the others.

You also have auditing issues because it is never clear which service did what as they share all the same identity.

If you are using different passwords for service foo, what is the problem in just creating foo-01 foo-02 foo-03 users instead ?

What problem does using the smae service user for all users resolve ?"}, {'account_id': 9098, 'date': '2013-11-22 16:27:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

"You don't suspend/disable the user credential, you suspend/disable the user."

This is true, and it highlights my concern about how this would work when Keystone is configured to use a LDAP server.  If a user's account is disabled or locked out in LDAP, they would still be able to authenticate in keystone using these additional passwords.  This allows one to bypass policies that may be defined on the LDAP server, such as account lockout after a number of failed authentication attempts.  The account would have to be disabled in LDAP and in Keystone, which defeats the purpose of a centralized identity source.

Thanks for explaining the password rotation case you are trying to solve.  If you must have a single account shared by multiple services and you want to be able to change the password without service interruption, you would need to allow multiple passwords.  That would have to be done with some control to prevent long-term use of multiple passwords.  When a password is changed, the old password could be marked for expiration and still allowed for use for some small grace period.  During this grace period, both passwords would be valid.  This grace period gives you time to update your services to use the new password.  This approach doesn't encourage the long-term use of multiple passwords.

Even if a a grace period approach was implemented in Keystone, there is still the issue of being able to bypass an external Identity Provider.  The external authentication source would need to support something similar to the grace period idea to support uninterrupted password rotation in this case.'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-11-23 02:36:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

@Simo

"Sharing the same user among multiple service when not necessary is a bad idea."

No are not sharing the same user among multiple services. Each services have their own unique service account. We are talking about sharing the credential among multiple instances of the same service, to enable CI/CD. Updating these credentials are done under a strict change control process (i.e. using chef and signed off by multile people). If we force all the instance to use a single password then rolling upgrade won't be possible without service interruption. Our security policy calls for service credential rotation after X number of days. Credential rotation are done via rolling upgrade.


"Besides causing you to want to have these odd features to store multiple passwords, it also means that if any one services is compromised then all of your other services are. So instead of blocking one now you may have to go and fix all the others."

As mentioned above, credentials are shared by instances of the same service, not among services. The risk is contained to a single service.

@Nathan

"This is true, and it highlights my concern about how this would work when Keystone is configured to use a LDAP server. If a user's account is disabled or locked out in LDAP, they would still be able to authenticate in keystone using these additional passwords. This allows one to bypass policies that may be defined on the LDAP server, such as account lockout after a number of failed authentication attempts. The account would have to be disabled in LDAP and in Keystone, which defeats the purpose of a centralized identity source."

We either authenticate against LDAP or Keystone (i.e. SQL) backend. If we are authenticating against both for a given user then this volunerable exist today in Keystone. This proposal does not change anything.


"Thanks for explaining the password rotation case you are trying to solve. If you must have a single account shared by multiple services and you want to be able to change the password without service interruption, you would need to allow multiple passwords. That would have to be done with some control to prevent long-term use of multiple passwords. When a password is changed, the old password could be marked for expiration and still allowed for use for some small grace period. During this grace period, both passwords would be valid. This grace period gives you time to update your services to use the new password. This approach doesn't encourage the long-term use of multiple passwords."

As mentioned above, credentials are shared by instances of the same service, not among services. The risk is contained to a single service. Besides, credential rotation are done under a strict change control process.

As I mentioned before, security is a process, software is a tool. Business process dictates security. All we are doing is to provide tools/options for customers to implement their business process.'}, {'account_id': 9098, 'date': '2013-11-24 02:10:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

@guang-yee
"As mentioned above, credentials are shared by instances of the same service, not among services. The risk is contained to a single service. Besides, credential rotation are done under a strict change control process.

As I mentioned before, security is a process, software is a tool. Business process dictates security. All we are doing is to provide tools/options for customers to implement their business process."

I think that software should try to enforce process/policy that results in the desired security instead of relying entirely on outside process.  This means secure default settings with flexibility to meet different security requirements.

I think that you have a valid use-case, but it should be solved in a way that Keystone is able to ensure that it is as secure as possible.  Let's summarize your use-case/requirements:

• Multiple instances of a service share a single user account in Keystone.
• Password changes must not interrupt services.

If I've captured your requirements correctly, you don't need to add an entirely new concept of "access keys".  I think all that would be needed to meet your requirements is a new configuration setting for Keystone.  The new configuration setting would control the "password changeover grace period".  The default setting would be 0, meaning that there is no grace period.  When a user password is changed, the old password is no longer valid.  If the grace period is set to a positive value (minutes, hours, whatever), the the old password remains valid for the grace period when a password is changed.  When the grace period expires, the old password is no longer valid.  In addition, only one previous password would ever be valid (to cover the case where a password is change multiple times within the grace period).

Does the above proposal meet your requirements?  It seems like a much more secure way of handling password changes without service interruption.  In addition, I'm not sure that this approach would require any API changes.'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-11-24 05:45:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

@Nathan

Please take a look at Fabio's other approach to solve this problem

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/55906/

It essentially introduce the concept of password expiration. However, it was shot down at the Summit because it involved core API changes.

Your approach would still involving maintaining both new and old passwords/shared secrets correct? But you are introducing a configurable option for Keystone.conf, which added more complexity.

I failed to understand what is not "secured by default" with the current proposal. Credential APIs are admin protected by default. User is allowed to have multiple credentials if and only if the process allows it. By default, only privileged users can set/update user credentials.'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-11-24 06:01:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

btw, I am all for adding the optional "expired_at" field into the shared secret credentials if it makes the proposal more agreeable. I don't think adding a universal configuration in Keystone.conf is the right approach. Credential management is strictly an administration function, not a deployment function.'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-11-24 22:55:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(7 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-11-24 23:33:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-11-26 21:19:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24: Do not merge

as captured in [1], this doesn't need to be an API-impacting change to satisfy the desired use case

[1]: https://gist.github.com/dolph/7366031/#password-rotation"}, {'account_id': 7052, 'date': '2013-12-04 01:23:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-12-11 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-12-11 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
OpenStack Identity API v3 OS-SHARED-SECRET Extension

Provide the ability for identity users to request a token using a shared
secret authorization method. This extension requires v3.0+ of the
Identity API.
The user provides a credential_id to identify the credential type and the
corresponding shared-secret information as secret.

blueprint access-key-authentication

Change-Id: Ibfbef444395e9eaa773a56839f38fa1697ebac64

commit_message:
Adding extra specs to flavor show and detail call

Adding a new extension in v3 which will add 'extra_specs'
to the flavor show and detail call. This will include the
extra_specs, along with the other information
related to the flavor.

Implements blueprint add-extra-specs-to-flavor-list

Change-Id: I432846ebbb0b7a0f06dc48abf9337084d75f1d3f

commit_message:
Clean-up files use

- file_hack was a hack used in Essex and now outdated.
- nothing is using nova-novncproxy.init

This patch aims to delete files/* and file_hack.pp which is now
useless.

Change-Id: I94b40e34fd61d778c7450d149f49e28612c58d31
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com>

commit_message:
Add metering agent support

The Ceilometer project is able to get meters from Neutron via the
notifications system on how much bandwidth the projects are using.
The idea is to meter this as the L3 routers levels.

The feature exists since Havana.

Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com>
implement blueprint metering-agent

Change-Id: I62ad9b7455e5f2bc3455b55a346f2515ca1040a3
(cherry picked from commit bf34f8631cfae0550dbe082740668df82f0cdfd4)

commit_message:
TTL mechanism support with expirer service

Aims to support a TTL mechanism for data entering Ceilometer
collector database.
TTL is very useful to configure when getting a lot of meters.

implement blueprint ttl-support
Change-Id: I9d98e8b833ad94fd79722dee7226e7f4f03aaa2e
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com>

[{'created': '2013-12-09 20:59:13.000000000', 'message': 'Sync minor updates in oslo.db module

* vim headers removed
* py3kcompat/urlutils functions used instead of urlparse
* log.warning() used instead of log.warn()
* license, typos and docstrings fixed
* locking fixed

Change-Id: I2a9bfc04ae473220da39cdf723247deba87dc07b

commit_message:
Sync minor updates in oslo.db module

* vim headers removed
* py3kcompat/urlutils functions used instead of urlparse
* log.warning() used instead of log.warn()
* license, typos and docstrings fixed
* locking fixed

Change-Id: I2a9bfc04ae473220da39cdf723247deba87dc07b

commit_message:
Add py3kcompat utils module

It's needed for the updated oslo.db code.
Currently it only provides urlutils.

Change-Id: Ieb25716930537a26e74d714db04678c7b81143cb

commit_message:
add more test cases to improve the test code coverage #5

In this patch, the following module test coverage improved to 100%

ceilometer/alarm/partition/coordination

Class PartitionIdentity was not tested for various method. This
patch set correct that problem. Also, class PartitionCoordinator
has 3 exception branches were not tested. This patch set added
more test cases to check these conditions.

Change-Id: Ia33a28e1650b6312843375af04973c9d5da2d89d

commit_message:
db.sqlalchemy.session add [sql].idle_timeout

Keystone is using idle_timeout in the [sql] section for the
idle timeout. Before Keystone can use oslo-incubator's
db.sqlalchemy.session we'll need to be able to have the old
option still be usable but deprecated.

bp use-common-oslo-db-code

Change-Id: Ic3dd4ec7f678f9564597830f9e4764d979a5d18a

commit_message:
Explicitly define "auth_region" in Neutron metadata_agent.ini

The default value for "auth_region" assumes "RegionOne" rather
than "regionOne" which causes the metadata agent to generate
authentication errors.

Change-Id: I0d3395a215eea7b3e3a9760a81e5f72a6bf523a4
Closes-Bug: #1259344

I strongly object to this change until the original code and original *interface* is fixed and/or cleaned up.

Here is the original implementation: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20294/

Although the original implementation works, the tests for it are bogus: It modifies the keystone response fixture when in reality keystone never returns such a response - the reason why the code even worked was because this change passed region_name to the constructor of ServiceCatalog when instantiating it in _extract_service_catalog.

The code broke when _extract_service_catalog was ripped out (and bah, note how _extract_service_catalog still lingers in the base HTTPClient class): https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20404/

I 100% agree that stuffing the region_name into the response we get from keystone is wrong. The one thing that is missing however from Jamie's change is that it does not maintain the existing interface/API. Here is the pseudo-test for that interface:

1. Instantiate the client with the region_name argument.
2. Call url_for on the service_catalog.
3. The returned value should be the endpoint for the region specified when the client was instantiated.

This what I mean by 'until the original code and original *interface* is fixed and/or cleaned up'. Once that's done, I'm fine with url_for growing an extra argument to override the region used for that call."}, {'account_id': 6917, 'date': '2013-10-10 14:18:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Hi Jamie and Cody,

I would like to ask you about progress with this patch. I really care about fixing this issue. How can I help with this patch? What can I do to speed things up?'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-10-10 18:50:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Side note- I released python-keystoneclient 0.4.0 yesterday and will happily release a minor version bump as soon as an agreeable solution to this issue is merged.'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-10-15 02:04:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-10-15 02:30:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Bartosz'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-10-21 16:34:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I've looked at it once and held off on reviewing it for a couple reasons:  it seems to be shuffling things around without really organizing the solution.  I am not sure versed on how it is consumed, but I think that region is really just one of the criteria that we are going to use to differentiate between two endpoints for the same service, and this patch  doesn't do anything to fix that.  I don't want to get in the way of others that can review it by giving it a negative review.  I am convinced that our approach to the client needs to be cleaned up, and I am researching tools to help do that.

I am not certain that I agree with the statement in the review summary:

"there is nothing specify to the token (or auth_data) that is region specific. Instead region information should be held by the client."    It seems to me that the token should encapsulate the minimal scope for an operation, and that the service catalog linked to a token should not include all possible endpoints for all possible regions.  Server side filtering will result in smaller tokens, and that is a huge benefit everywhere.

I suspect that you are pushing for a client side solution due to a specific set of use cases that cross beyond regional boundaries.  We have an API review (abandoned, but should come back to life) that addresses making Regions a first class object:  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/27563/'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-10-21 17:43:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

haven't done a thorough review but tests look great"}, {'account_id': 6223, 'date': '2013-10-21 22:05:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I would prefer that the refactoring of how we do filtering (ie. the introduction of _filter) be separated out into a separate branch. (If you're strongly opposed to that, at the very least there should be a few specific tests for it).

I'd also like to get more information about how you want this to work in the future. Do you want to deprecate the region_name argument to HTTPClient's constructor or just AccessInfo and/or ServiceCatalog's knowledge of it? If the later, how do you intend for the region_name to continue to work?

Broader picture, I'm thinking AccessInfo shouldn't even know about ServiceCatalog and should be created by HTTPClient not AccessInfo.

Will you be at ODS? Would be nice to be able to chat further in person."}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-10-22 00:00:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-10-22 00:06:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Sorry for splitting this up just as it was getting to finished but ayoung is kind of right. The rearrangements of the service catalog make it really difficult to see what is happening to fix the actual bug. 

I extracted that out into a dependent review. Please have a look through that as well.'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-10-22 00:18:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

@ayoung: I'll try to put that another way. The AccessInfo and Service catalog are representations of information that is held in the token. If you scope the service catalog when requesting it from the server that's fine, it means that the available endpoints within a ServiceCatalog object will be less. What i'm saying is that as a representation of returned data it does not make sense to set attributes on a ServiceCatalog object. The ServiceCatalog should ONLY be queried to find a url that matches what you want to use. Setting region_name on the ServiceCatalog is doing a similar thing to what would have happened if you scoped the token call by always hiding some of the returned urls and this is wrong. 

@cody: Just the AccessInfo's knowledge of the region. As above AccessInfo is a wrapper to help you get data out of the token, what data you want to retrieve should be based on the questions you ask of it, not on a variable set on the wrapper.

If we have a situation where swift and keystone are sharing a ServiceCatalog. I'm not sure if they do currently but as it's a keystone thing they should be. If i set my keystone wants to be in the 'US' region then it should find the appropriate URL. Swift for speed may need to be closer to home and have 'EastCoast', 'Central', and 'WestCoast' regions. 

As it stands now the US region will be set permanently on the ServiceCatalog and affect Swift in requesting a different region.

So the client still needs to know about region_name, and when it does a service_catalog.url_for it should provide the region_name that it requires as a parameter to the url_for function so as not to interfere with other users of that ServiceCatalog.


Yee, i'll be at summit and will be happy to have a chat about it ."}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-10-22 00:21:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

@cody: as for AccessInfo knowing about the ServiceCatalog, i can't see any reason for them to talk to each other but the ServiceCatalog is returned as part of the AccessInfo so i think the relationship needs to happen in that way. 

A more interesting question to my mind is that if the ServiceCatalog is just a subsection of the AccessInfo's data why do we need the ServiceCatalog object at all? Why don't we just merge it into AccessInfo?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-10-22 00:34:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-01 07:08:53.000000000', 'message': 'Properly handle Regions in keystoneclient

Region name is taken as a parameter but is ignored in all communication
with the service catalog. Region is something that belongs in most url
selection functions so add them there and add deprecation comments to a
number of places where the old functionality is incorrect.

Whilst there clean up a lot of the service catalog functions to provide
some more common functionality. This reveals some targets for cleanup
later but at the moment all the old behaviour is maintained.

Fixes bug 1147530

Change-Id: I812aa89c8b4af28e294e63926a7f88e8246fffc5
'}, {'created': '2013-10-02 00:31:48.000000000', 'message': 'Properly handle Regions in keystoneclient

Region name is taken as a parameter but is ignored in all communication
with the service catalog. Currently region can be stored in the token
data and then requests to url functions will return the appropriate
region. This is the wrong approach because there is nothing specifiy to
the token (or auth_data) that is region specific. Instead region
information should be held by the client.

Add the ability to query region to url functions. Also do some cleanup
to provide common functions between the v2 and v3 service catalog.

Fixes bug 1147530

Change-Id: I812aa89c8b4af28e294e63926a7f88e8246fffc5
'}, {'created': '2013-10-02 23:45:15.000000000', 'message': 'Properly handle Regions in keystoneclient

commit_message:
Properly handle Regions in keystoneclient

Region name is taken as a parameter but is ignored in all communication
with the service catalog. Currently region can be stored in the token
data and then requests to url functions will return the appropriate
region. This is the wrong approach because there is nothing specific to
the token (or auth_data) that is region specific. Instead region
information should be held by the client.

Closes-Bug: 1147530
Closes-Bug: 1255992
Change-Id: I812aa89c8b4af28e294e63926a7f88e8246fffc5

Also I think, that will be better remove this code (if we plan don't support old style) in separate patch."}, {'account_id': 7225, 'date': '2013-12-10 07:05:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: No score

I tend to agree, but i have one more concern about 'members' property. We assign created Health Monitors to the Load Balancer as 'health_monitors' property on Load Balancer resource.

In case of PoolMember we do the otherwise - refer to Pool from PoolMember. This is done because two Load Balancers can have same set of Health Monitors?"}, {'account_id': 7225, 'date': '2013-12-10 07:09:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

About removing obsolete code with separate patch: we are introducing a new way of creating Pool Members, and this is may interfere with old-one. What if some-one use both way's for one server?

Also, note that new way does not provide ability to use Instance resource as a reference (as was previously) for the new member. It's meen that PollMember becames tied directly to the IP address."}, {'account_id': 7225, 'date': '2013-12-10 07:28:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: No score

'}, {'account_id': 6577, 'date': '2013-12-10 08:09:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@Serg: Yep. I agree with you, that it seems dangerous (when we have 2 ways for creating members). 
Other side you may create a bug with this issue (2 conflict ways for creating members) and fix it immediately. This way, I think, will be better, because you show code changes step-by-step.

About using Instance reference - you are right. Unfortunately we will lost it. Anyway you can do such:
"members": { "GetAtt" : ["server1", "PrivateIP"]}
instead
"members": { "Ref" : "server1"}
It also get benefit: data model in heat became similar with model in neutron. (because in neutron you should set IP address too).'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-12-10 22:26:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

the members property can be deprecated when we have some way of deprecating properties'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-12-10 22:26:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: No score

commit_message:
Add load balancer PoolMember resource

This adds a new resource to manage the relationship between a load
balancing pool and an address, allowing more options like setting the
weight of the member.

Change-Id: Ic8a55ff8b8b00c7a4e3184b3028d5bf0cdd5c916
Implements: blueprint loadbalancer-pool-members

commit_message:
Pin sphinx to <1.2

There is a bug in sphinx 1.2 that breaks doc builds.

See requirements commit 0e8862e958813a031fe7398440e8a3866b42a8e4
for details.

Related-Bug: 1259511

Change-Id: I50c2102ed3c088254d1c03638ebe585d9dfe6622

commit_message:
remove  test_service_enable_disable in nova V3 tests

additional patch for change Ib681b393944b37c720e7a245e8b19b5254d116fd:
this removes the test: test_service_enable_disable, due to race
condition. And there is a discussion in the mail list.
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-November/018867.html

Change-Id: I7d54a72b45cb31e483f6833a12453d1a5cecdf61
Closes-bug: #1257506

[{'created': '2013-12-03 05:46:27.000000000', 'message': 'Add OS::Neutron::NetDhcpAgent for neutron/net.py

This resourse supports part of
"agent management and scheduler extensions" in Neutron.
It associates network with dhcp-agent.

I think, it may be needed by administrators who
want to decide agents to work. (e.g. to use HA functionality)

Fixes bug #1245366

I think, it may be needed by administrators who want to decide agents to
work. (e.g. to use HA functionality)

Change-Id: I3dc663c4c51824bd3e69c74ff1d9b50a8ce598c9
'}]
commit_message:
Add OS::Neutron::NetDHCPAgent for neutron/net.py

This resource supports part of "agent management and scheduler
extensions" in Neutron.  It associates network with dhcp-agent.

I think, it may be needed by administrators who want to decide agents to
work. (e.g. to use HA functionality)

Closes-bug: #1245366
Change-Id: I3dc663c4c51824bd3e69c74ff1d9b50a8ce598c9

commit_message:
Fix $TARGET_ROOT usage in yum element

Fix the test for $TARGET_ROOT in root.d/50-yum-cache.

Don't use $TARGET_ROOT in pre-install, it's only set for "root" and "cleanup".

Change-Id: I048364ea08ef503a4466f3494f18f72ebf99b5c2

commit_message:
Sync global requirements to pin sphinx to sphinx>=1.1.2,<1.2

Sync the global requirements to pin sphinx.  This addresses an issue
where Sphinx 1.2 is not building documents correctly and causing
check/gate to fail.

Change-Id: Id4a54ec708102e35602e87ee9773ca119ce5b4f6

Sync global requirements to pin sphinx to sphinx>=1.1.2,<1.2

Sync the global requirements to pin sphinx.  This addresses an issue
where Sphinx 1.2 is not building documents correctly and causing
check/gate to fail.

We also had to adjust the pip command used.

Change-Id: I8894c0199db845e90e5086a7c0e6bb7c7a26b5a0

'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-12-03 01:34:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(2 inline comments)

I think `fd3b64bb` introduced the self._patch and self._patchers' stop calls, which can be a problematic pattern; see the note about "addCleanup" on http://www.voidspace.org.uk/python/mock/patch.html#patch-methods-start-and-stop

I hate to see more of that going in, but you can claim prior art if you must.

If I was attacking this I probably would have gone after concrete assertions on the *behavior* of the real the account and container replicators, exercising at least the *real* merge_items calls and picking up the method dispatch, error handling, and system call side effects of the base class along the way.  But... I'm not and you are - so I can deal.

I have a few other tactical grievances notated inline, but I'll still +2 because "more tests".'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-12-03 01:55:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Clay: addCleanup() is python2.7-only, isn't it?"}, {'account_id': 9275, 'date': '2013-12-03 02:25:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

@Darrell , i cannot find any addCleanup() call on this patch.'}, {'account_id': 9275, 'date': '2013-12-03 02:33:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

@Darrell i misunderstood the comment. Yes, addCleanup seems to be supported on 2.7 ,3.1, 3.2 and 3. 3. but not not on python 2.6 so that gate may fail, is that your point?'}, {'account_id': 9450, 'date': '2013-12-03 12:13:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-12-03 15:49:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I was just pointing out that switching to use addCleanup, while "safer", is not an option since Swift unit tests have to run on python 2.6.

Maybe we could include a backported-from-python-2.7 unittest2 module so we can use addCleanup, assertNotIn, and other fancy-pants asserts which were added later?  I think Django did that for consistency between python 2.6 and python 2.7.'}, {'account_id': 9225, 'date': '2013-12-03 16:38:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

I have made some changes pointed in the inline comments. Also I replaced many calls to self._patch to use 'with patch(...)', I didn't do it for all because nesting with statements would make the code less clear. Another patch is coming...  

I can also submit a bug to make the changes to include unittest2 in swift."}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-12-03 16:40:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Darrell - thanks for pointing out that 'addCleanup' is a python 2.7ism - that's all the more reason that we should be trying to stick to the use patch decorators and context managers instead of expanding the usage of getting it wrong/as-little-incorrect-as-possible with patch start and stop in the setup and teardown methods.

Still fine with merging it as-is, I think the extra test coverage is worth the cost of the maintenance overhead.  I just wanted to raise the issues I saw to the author."}, {'account_id': 9225, 'date': '2013-12-03 17:01:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-12-03 17:09:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Increases the UT coverage of db_replicator.py

Adds 20 unit tests to increase the coverage of db_replicator.py
from 71% to 90%

Change-Id: Ia63cb8f2049fb3182bbf7af695087bfe15cede54
Closes-Bug: #948179

commit_message:
Sync global requirements to pin sphinx to sphinx>=1.1.2,<1.2

Sync the global requirements to pin sphinx.  This addresses an issue
where Sphinx 1.2 is not building documents correctly and causing
check/gate to fail.

Change-Id: I92af6481d2fdfaea6eda4eaffb0388eeaea8cb9f

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-10 21:43:05.000000000', 'message': "Pin Sphinx to <1.2

1.2 was just released and has a bug that causes builds to fail with
the error:

  error: 'source_dir' must be a directory name (got `...doc/source`)

See: http://bugs.python.org/issue19570
and: https://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/sphinx/pull-request/193/builddoc-shouldnt-fail-on-unicode-paths/diff

Change-Id: I0487b4eca8f2755b882689289e3cdf429729b1fb
"}]
commit_message:
Pin Sphinx to <1.2

1.2 was just released and has a bug that causes builds to fail with
the error:

  error: 'source_dir' must be a directory name (got `...doc/source`)

See: http://bugs.python.org/issue19570
and: https://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/sphinx/pull-request/193/builddoc-shouldnt-fail-on-unicode-paths/diff

Change-Id: I0487b4eca8f2755b882689289e3cdf429729b1fb

commit_message:
Pin Sphinx to <1.2

1.2 was just released and has a bug that causes builds to fail with
the error:

  error: 'source_dir' must be a directory name (got `...doc/source`)

See: http://bugs.python.org/issue19570
and: https://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/sphinx/pull-request/193/builddoc-shouldnt-fail-on-unicode-paths/diff

Change-Id: Ic3920c893630d10780f4e6b42451f6b2c1837a66
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <paul.belanger@polybeacon.com>
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <paul.belanger@polybeacon.com>
